abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Ho Chi Minh City
            Investment Fund for Urban (HIFU) Development Project for
            Vietnam were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: among the major challenges encountered
            during project implementation was the difficulty of many
            prospective private sector investors in complying with the
            project's safeguard and fiduciary guidelines, which
            were not fully consistent with Government of Vietnam (GOV)
            laws and policies. The efforts to move towards adopting
            country systems for safeguards and fiduciary guidelines
            should be continued by the Vietnam country team. The lack of
            specific GOV legal guidelines requiring the competitive
            selection of private sector partners as part of the
            establishment of a new legal entity, Special Purpose Vehicle
            (SPV) served as a disincentive for prospective private
            investors to participate in direct equity investment
            sub-projects under HIFU Development Project (HDP). The
            financing agreement and Project Appraisal Document (PAD) of
            HDP provided for possible amendments to the project manuals
            subject to the clearance of the Bank and a resolution of the
            Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee (HCMC PC). In cases
            such as HDP where project implementation was affected by the
            challenges in applying certain guidelines of the project
            manual, such as those pertaining to procurement and
            safeguards, the Borrower should be strongly encouraged to
            review and to formally propose amendments. In the case of
            HDP where there was an open menu for sub-projects, Ho Chi
            Minh City Finance and Investment State Owned Company (HFIC)
            should have been provided with the flexibility to appraise
            eligible sub-projects in its pipeline on a first-come, first
            served basis. In the absence of such requirements, the Bank
            should not have postponed the appraisal of sub-projects from
            certain sectors in favor of other those from other sectors,
            particularly in the context where disbursement levels were
            generally below targets. HFIC generally complied with the
            financial covenants of the project with the exception of
            isolated incidents that were a result of directed
            investments of HCMC PC in sub-projects that were channeled
            through HFIC. The sequenced preparation and implementation
            of HDP and Local Development Investment Fund Project (LDIFP)
            has strategically allowed the Bank to distill and apply
            lessons from the implementation of HDP to the design and
            implementation of LDIFP in real-time. In the case of HDP
            which was implemented in very constrained economic
            conditions for private sector investors, the strong
            commitment of HCMC PC and HFIC to promote the project to the
            investor community, to provide technical assistance to
            private sector partners in applying the project manual, and
            to collaborate very closely with the Bank team in
            continuously developing the pipeline of subprojects and
            appraising potential sub-projects, were critical in ensuring
            the achievement of the Project Development Objective (PDO)
            and the commitment of the full International Development
            Association (IDA) credit.
